The members of this informal group changed over time but in the introduction to ESSAYS PRESENTED TO CHARLES WILLIAMS

CS Lewis mentions prominent members: Dorothy L. Sayers, JRR Tolkien,

Owen Barfield, WH Lewis, Gervase Matthews, etc. There are references too in other works. But as I am away from my home and library these are limited by my memory. Best wishes.

George MacDonald was not an Inkling physically, though he was no doubt literarily and spiritually considered one. He was an author who had much influence on CSL and JRRT. He was deceased I think when the Inklings met. If you refer to JRRT's "On Fairy Stories" in the essay collection mentioned, you'll find references to GMcD.

George MacDonald was not an Inkling physically, though he was no doubt literarily and spiritually considered one. He was an author who had much influence on CSL and JRRT. He was deceased I think when the Inklings met. If you refer to JRRT's "On Fairy Stories" in the essay collection mentioned, you'll find references to GMcD.

DL Sayers was never an Inkling nor did she ever attend a meeting. She corresponded with Lewis, and Tolkien enjoyed her early Whimsey books, though not Gaudy Night as I recall, but none of them ever met in real life. She does share many of the intellectual and spiritual ideas of the Inklings however.

To add to the list, Hugo Dyson, Neville Coghill, Bede Griffiths, were among those who attended at times. The best places to find reference to those who did attend would first _The Inklings_ by Humphrey Carpenter and _Brothers and Friends_ which are the edited journals of W. H. Lewis, the secretary of the Inklings when he was in England. He often mentions and lists the names of those in attendance in his journals.

Giles

Good Sir,

Perhaps I read too much into the following found on the initial page of the PREFACE to ESSAYS PRESENTED TO CHARLES WILLIAMS:

"If the authors of this book were to put forward any claim, it would be, and that shyly, that they were for the last few years of his life a fairly permanent nucleus among his literary friends. He read us his manuscripts and we read him ours: we smoked, talked, argued, and drank together (I must confess that with Miss Dorothy Sayers I have seen him drink only tea: but that was neither his fault nor hers)."

It would seem that at least these three (CSL, DLS, CW) had met and imbibed at least tea together. This may not have been an Inklings meeting in Lewis' rooms. ... But, I have nagging in the deeper neurons a half recollected account of one such meeting at which I believe she was present. As I have returned home I shall attempt to dredge up the supporting data if any.

Your thoughts?

Postscript: On checking my references I find no less an authority than WH Lewis (Major, ret.) asserting in a diary entry Thursday 5th January 1967 in response to a book re: the Inklings by Moorman (The Precincts of Felicity) that "when in the last chapter he brings in T.S. Eliot and Dorothy Sayers, neither of whom ever attended an Inklings in their lives"

that ... (mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa) my memory was

WRONG. It was undoubtedly a very old neuron which had switched polarity under the intervening years overindulgences or protein over-accumulation... . Of your courtesies, sirs, I humbly beg pardon. And if I offended any ladies in this error, I most humbly crave your pardons as well. I shall endeavor to do better in any future posts.

Inklings members:

See BROTHERS & FRIENDS : The Diaries of Major Hamilton Lewis

entry Tuesday 15 May 1945 footnote #202 for a compilation list by the editors of the extensive "regular members" (tho' the editors observe that this did not mean all were regularly present and take pains to note that

'intermittent invited guests were not uncommon').

And since there are nearly 20 names, you'll have to look it up and fair copy it out.

By the way, on perusing the index of B&F I discovered an entry on

11th November 1947 in which Major Lewis is recollecting a morning Inklings (rather "thin") at which the topic of discussion was the newly published essays to Charles Williams, and I find that the footnote to this by the editors #230 discusses the inclusion of DL Sayers essay and the reasons for its inclusion. That old neuron mentioned in the earlier post undoubtedly sent an axon to the Bird and Baby neuron and another to the DLS neuron. The axon then fired from each linked neuron and voila

my egress error! (Could this sort of apologia ever really be acceptable?)

I should be very glad if anyone has read anywhere of the meeting CSL alludes to in the Preface to EPTCW. It would do me good penance to seek it and read it myself.:teary:

Inked,

No need to apologize as far as I'm concerned. Many included Sayers among the Inklings, though as Warne points out she never attended a meeting, at least so far as he knew.

As you are no doubt aware, DLS and CW were acquainted. DLS had published by the end of the war with Oxford Univ. Press, where CW worked, and of course DLS was indebted and very much respected CW's work on Dante's Beatrice as DLS was preparing her own Dante Papers. It is that acquaintanceship, methinks, that people often take as indicating that DLS was an Inkling.

As for the reference in the the front of the book of essays you mention, I'm aware of the book and read it some years ago, but don't recall that note. Not that its not there, but I don't recall it. But I trust you, so I'll apologize for stating that CSL had never met DLS in person.

Cheers,

Giles

Attalus,

I believe that the point of the Essays was that all contributors were friends of Charles Williams, not necessarily of each other. JRRT seems to have enjoyed the Lord Peter series until the intro of Harriet Vane and the ongoing relationship development through Gaudy Night by which time he found the series intolerable and derivatively its authoress (creatrix).

Now it is extremely interesting that CS Lewis discusses just this situation in THE FOUR LOVES under "Philia". He remarks how one can enjoy another's conversation without liking the person. This certainly was Tolkien's approach to Charles Williams.

Given the info above and the physical absence of DLS per WH Lewis, I don't think JRRT and DLS were ever more than literarily aquainted. Also I am unaware or not recollecting any comment of JRRT on Sayers DANTE or her theological works. Any thread readers who know otherwise, please share the reference and enlighten me.

Giles,

Point taken. JRRT did contribute the essay, so I did not intend to imply that he had antipathy for CW. But, certainly he and CW were not "buds". I am amazed at how the Inklings functioned and related so well when they were all so remarkably individuals and diversely interested. Personal feelings were hit or miss. Literature and criticism of each others works and ideas were the commonality, not likings per se.
